title: Annual Routine Physical Examination
content:
Patient presented for annual routine physical examination. Patient reports feeling generally well with no major health concerns.

Chief Complaint:
Routine annual checkup - no specific complaints

Current Medications:
- Multivitamin once daily
- No prescription medications

Vital Signs:
- Blood Pressure: 118/76 mmHg (normal)
- Heart Rate: 68 bpm, regular
- Respiratory Rate: 16 breaths/min
- Temperature: 98.6°F (37°C)
- Height: 170 cm (5'7")
- Weight: 68 kg (150 lbs)
- BMI: 23.5 (normal range)
- Oxygen Saturation: 98% on room air

Review of Systems:
- General: No fever, chills, or unintentional weight changes
- Cardiovascular: No chest pain, palpitations, or leg swelling
- Respiratory: No shortness of breath, cough, or wheezing
- Gastrointestinal: No abdominal pain, nausea, or changes in bowel habits
- Musculoskeletal: No joint pain or muscle weakness
- Neurological: No headaches, dizziness, or numbness
- Skin: No new rashes or lesions

Physical Examination:
- General Appearance: Well-appearing, alert and oriented x3, no acute distress
- HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. Pupils equal, round, reactive to light. Tympanic membranes clear. Oral mucosa moist, no lesions
- Neck: Supple, no lymphadenopathy, thyroid non-palpable
- Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. S1 and S2 normal
- Respiratory: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi
- Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Normal bowel sounds. No hepatosplenomegaly
- Extremities: No edema, cyanosis, or clubbing. Peripheral pulses 2+ bilaterally
- Neurological: Cranial nerves II-XII grossly intact. Motor strength 5/5 in all extremities. Reflexes 2+ and symmetric
- Skin: No concerning rashes or lesions noted

Laboratory Results (Fasting):
Complete Blood Count:
- Hemoglobin: 14.2 g/dL (normal)
- White Blood Cell Count: 7,200/μL (normal)
- Platelet Count: 245,000/μL (normal)

Comprehensive Metabolic Panel:
- Fasting Glucose: 92 mg/dL (normal)
- Sodium: 140 mEq/L (normal)
- Potassium: 4.1 mEq/L (normal)
- Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL (normal kidney function)
- eGFR: >90 mL/min/1.73m² (excellent)
- ALT: 28 U/L (normal)
- AST: 24 U/L (normal)
- Total Bilirubin: 0.8 mg/dL (normal)

Lipid Panel:
- Total Cholesterol: 178 mg/dL (desirable)
- LDL Cholesterol: 98 mg/dL (optimal)
- HDL Cholesterol: 58 mg/dL (good)
- Triglycerides: 110 mg/dL (normal)

Other Tests:
- TSH: 2.1 mIU/L (normal thyroid function)
- Vitamin D: 42 ng/mL (sufficient)
- Urinalysis: Normal, no abnormalities detected
diagnosis:
Healthy Adult - No Acute Medical Issues

Patient is in excellent health with all vital signs, physical examination findings, and laboratory results within normal limits. No chronic medical conditions identified.

Health Maintenance Status:
- Annual physical examination: Completed today
- Age-appropriate screenings: Up to date
- Vaccinations: Current (last updated 6 months ago)
- Overall risk assessment: Low cardiovascular risk

Preventive Care:
All age-appropriate preventive care measures are current.
prescription:
No Prescription Medications Required

Continue Current Regimen:
1. Multivitamin - Continue taking 1 tablet daily

Over-the-Counter Recommendations:
- Continue daily multivitamin for general health maintenance
- Consider Omega-3 supplement 1000mg daily for cardiovascular health (optional)
- Calcium 600mg with Vitamin D 400IU daily for bone health (optional)

No prescription medications are needed at this time given excellent health status.
recommendations:
General Health Maintenance:
1. Continue current healthy lifestyle practices
2. Maintain healthy diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins
3. Continue regular physical activity (current routine is adequate)
4. Maintain healthy sleep schedule (7-9 hours per night)
5. Practice stress management techniques

Physical Activity:
1. Continue current exercise routine
2. Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic activity per week
3. Include strength training exercises 2-3 times per week
4. Incorporate flexibility and balance exercises

Nutrition:
1. Maintain balanced, varied diet
2. Limit processed foods and added sugars
3. Stay well-hydrated (8-10 glasses of water daily)
4. Moderate alcohol consumption (if any)
5. Limit sodium intake to <2,300 mg per day

Preventive Care Schedule:
1. Next annual physical examination: Schedule in 12 months
2. Dental checkup: Every 6 months (next due in 6 months)
3. Eye examination: Every 2 years (next due in 18 months)
4. Skin examination: Annual self-checks, professional exam if any concerning changes

Screenings (based on age and gender):
1. Blood pressure: Check annually
2. Cholesterol: Recheck in 5 years (unless risk factors develop)
3. Diabetes screening: Every 3 years starting at age 45
4. Colorectal cancer screening: Starting at age 45-50 (discuss options)
5. Age and gender-specific cancer screenings as recommended

Vaccinations:
1. Influenza vaccine: Annually (next due in fall)
2. Tetanus booster: Every 10 years
3. COVID-19: Keep up to date per current guidelines
4. Other vaccines as recommended based on age, occupation, and travel

Lifestyle Recommendations:
1. Maintain healthy weight (current BMI is optimal)
2. Avoid tobacco products
3. Limit alcohol consumption
4. Practice safe sun exposure (sunscreen SPF 30+)
5. Use seat belts and practice safe driving
6. Regular hand washing and hygiene practices

Mental Health:
1. Practice stress management
2. Maintain social connections
3. Seek help if experiencing mood changes, anxiety, or depression
4. Consider mindfulness or meditation practices

When to Contact Healthcare Provider:
1. Development of new symptoms or health concerns
2. Changes in existing health conditions
3. Questions about medications or treatments
4. Need for acute care or urgent concerns
5. Before starting new medications or supplements

Emergency Warning Signs (Seek Immediate Care):
- Severe chest pain or pressure
- Difficulty breathing
- Sudden severe headache
- Loss of consciousness
- Severe bleeding
- Signs of stroke (facial drooping, arm weakness, speech difficulty)

Overall Assessment:
Patient is in excellent health and should continue current health practices. No concerns identified during this comprehensive evaluation.
